name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
repair_prompt:
The new generation external memory includes an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. However, it allows for a different kind of operation that can be used to modify the array. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you substitute the segment a[l … r] with its cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 


For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5] 

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
completion:
def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    """Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]."""
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure the offset is within the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    """Sort the array using cyclic shifts and return the operations."""
    operations = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return operations  # Already sorted, no operations needed
    
    # Simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n - 1):
            if arr[j] > arr[j + 1]:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to swap arr[j] and arr[j+1]
                cyclic_shift(arr, j, j + 1, 1)
                operations.append((j + 1, j + 2, 1))
    
    return operations

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        
        operations = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append((len(operations), operations))
    
    for k, ops in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in ops:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()
completions:
def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    actions = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return actions  # Already sorted, no actions needed
    
    # Simple strategy: repeatedly find the largest unsorted segment and shift it
    for i in range(n):
        if arr[i:] != sorted_arr[i:]:
            # Find the first unsorted segment
            l = i
            r = n - 1
            while r > l and arr[r] == sorted_arr[r]:
                r -= 1
            
            # Perform a cyclic shift to move the smallest element to the front
            min_index = arr.index(min(arr[l:r+1]), l, r+1)
            d = min_index - l
            cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d)
            actions.append((l + 1, r + 1, d))
    
    return actions

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        
        actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append(actions)
    
    for actions in results:
        print(len(actions))
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def parse_input():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += 2
    return test_cases

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, array):
    operations = []
    sorted_array = sorted(array)
    
    if array == sorted_array:
        return operations
    
    # Simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n - 1):
            if array[j] > array[j + 1]:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to swap array[j] and array[j+1]
                array = cyclic_shift(array, j, j + 1, 1)
                operations.append((j + 1, j + 2, 1))
                if len(operations) >= n:
                    return operations
    
    return operations

def main():
    test_cases = parse_input()
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        operations = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, array)
        results.append((len(operations), operations))
    
    for k, ops in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in ops:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for case in test_cases:
        n, a = case
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the correct position of a[i] in the sorted array
                correct_pos = sorted_a.index(a[i], i)
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move a[i] to its correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = correct_pos + 1
                d = r - l
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = a[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                if a == sorted_a:
                    break
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for i in range(t):
        n, a = test_cases[i]
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # Simple strategy: repeatedly find the largest unsorted segment and shift it
        for _ in range(n):
            if a == sorted_a:
                break
            
            # Find the largest unsorted segment
            l, r = 0, 0
            for j in range(n - 1):
                if a[j] > a[j + 1]:
                    l = j
                    while r < n - 1 and a[r] > a[r + 1]:
                        r += 1
                    break
            
            # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment
            if l < r:
                d = 1  # Shift by 1 to the left
                segment = a[l:r+1]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l:r+1] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l + 1, r + 1, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        a = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform cyclic shift on the segment arr[l:r+1] to the left by d positions
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    actions = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return 0, actions
    
    # Simple strategy: repeatedly find the smallest unsorted element and move it to the correct position
    for i in range(n):
        if arr[i] != sorted_arr[i]:
            # Find the position of the element that should be at index i
            correct_pos = arr.index(sorted_arr[i], i)
            # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to the correct position
            if correct_pos > i:
                arr = cyclic_shift(arr, i, correct_pos, correct_pos - i)
                actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, correct_pos - i))
    
    return len(actions), actions

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        arr = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        index += 2
        
        k, actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append(f"{k}")
        for action in actions:
            results.append(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")
    
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for i in range(t):
        n, array = test_cases[i]
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        operations = []
        
        # Simple strategy: repeatedly find the largest unsorted segment and shift it
        for j in range(n):
            if array == sorted_array:
                break
            
            # Find the first unsorted segment
            for l in range(n - 1):
                if array[l] > array[l + 1]:
                    break
            
            # Find the end of the unsorted segment
            for r in range(l + 1, n):
                if array[r] < array[r - 1]:
                    continue
                else:
                    break
            else:
                r = n
            
            # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment
            d = 1  # Shift by 1 to the left
            segment = array[l:r]
            shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
            array[l:r] = shifted_segment
            
            operations.append((l + 1, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(operations), operations))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        array = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    for k, operations in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in operations:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    actions = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return actions  # Already sorted, no actions needed
    
    # Simple strategy: repeatedly find the smallest unsorted element and move it to the correct position
    for i in range(n):
        if arr[i] != sorted_arr[i]:
            # Find the position of the element that should be at index i
            correct_pos = arr.index(sorted_arr[i], i)
            # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to the correct position
            if correct_pos > i:
                cyclic_shift(arr, i, correct_pos, correct_pos - i)
                actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, correct_pos - i))
    
    return actions

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        
        actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    """Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]."""
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    """Sort the array using cyclic shifts and return the operations."""
    operations = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return operations  # Already sorted, no operations needed
    
    # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        if arr[i] != sorted_arr[i]:
            # Find the position of the correct element
            correct_pos = arr.index(sorted_arr[i], i)
            # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the correct element to position i
            if correct_pos > i:
                d = correct_pos - i
                arr = cyclic_shift(arr, i, correct_pos, d)
                operations.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))
    
    return operations

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        
        operations = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append((len(operations), operations))
    
    for result in results:
        k, operations = result
        print(k)
        for op in operations:
            print(*op)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform cyclic shift on the segment arr[l:r+1] to the left by d positions
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    actions = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    # If the array is already sorted, return 0 actions
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return actions
    
    # Implement a simple sorting strategy using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        if arr[i] != sorted_arr[i]:
            # Find the position of the correct element in the unsorted array
            correct_pos = arr.index(sorted_arr[i], i)
            # Perform a cyclic shift to move the correct element to the current position
            if correct_pos > i:
                actions.append((i, correct_pos, correct_pos - i))
                arr = cyclic_shift(arr, i, correct_pos, correct_pos - i)
    
    return actions

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index+n]))
        index += n
        
        actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l + 1, r + 1, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    """Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]."""
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure the offset is within the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    """Sort the array using cyclic shifts and return the operations."""
    operations = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return operations  # Already sorted, no operations needed
    
    # Simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n - 1):
            if arr[j] > arr[j + 1]:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to swap arr[j] and arr[j+1]
                cyclic_shift(arr, j, j + 1, 1)
                operations.append((j + 1, j + 2, 1))
    
    return operations

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    """Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]."""
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure the offset is within the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    """Sort the array using cyclic shifts and return the operations."""
    operations = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return operations  # Already sorted, no operations needed
    
    # Simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n - 1):
            if arr[j] > arr[j + 1]:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to swap arr[j] and arr[j+1]
                cyclic_shift(arr, j, j + 1, 1)
                operations.append((j + 1, j + 2, 1))
    
    return operations

        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        
        operations = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append((len(operations), operations))
    
    for k, ops in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in ops:
            print(l, r, d)

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform a cyclic shift to the left by d on the segment arr[l:r+1]
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    arr[l:r+1] = shifted_segment

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    actions = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return actions  # Already sorted, no actions needed
    
    # Simple strategy: repeatedly find the largest unsorted segment and shift it
    for i in range(n):
        if arr[i:] != sorted_arr[i:]:
            # Find the first unsorted segment
            l = i
            r = n - 1
            while r > l and arr[r] == sorted_arr[r]:
                r -= 1
            
            # Perform a cyclic shift to move the smallest element to the front
            min_index = arr.index(min(arr[l:r+1]), l, r+1)
            d = min_index - l
            cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d)
            actions.append((l + 1, r + 1, d))
    
    return actions

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        
        actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append(actions)
    
    for actions in results:
        print(len(actions))
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

def cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases):
    results = []
    
    for case in test_cases:
        n, a = case
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the correct position of a[i] in the sorted array
                correct_pos = sorted_a.index(a[i], i)
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to move a[i] to its correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = correct_pos + 1
                d = r - l
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = a[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                if a == sorted_a:
                    break
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])

    for _ in range(t):

        test_cases.append((n, a))

def cyclic_shift(arr, l, r, d):
    # Perform cyclic shift on the segment arr[l:r+1] to the left by d positions
    segment = arr[l:r+1]
    d = d % len(segment)  # Ensure d is within the bounds of the segment length
    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
    return arr[:l] + shifted_segment + arr[r+1:]

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr):
    actions = []
    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return 0, actions
    
    # Simple strategy: repeatedly find the smallest unsorted element and move it to the correct position
    for i in range(n):
        if arr[i] != sorted_arr[i]:
            # Find the position of the element that should be at index i
            correct_pos = arr.index(sorted_arr[i], i)
            # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to the correct position
            if correct_pos > i:
                arr = cyclic_shift(arr, i, correct_pos, correct_pos - i)
                actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, correct_pos - i))
    
    return len(actions), actions

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        arr = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        index += 2
        
        k, actions = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append(f"{k}")
        for action in actions:
            results.append(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")
    
    print("\n".join(results))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

    results = []

        if array == sorted_array:

            if array == sorted_array:
                break
            
            # Find the first unsorted segment
            for l in range(n - 1):
                if array[l] > array[l + 1]:
                    break
            
            # Find the end of the unsorted segment
            for r in range(l + 1, n):
                if array[r] < array[r - 1]:
                    continue
                else:

            # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment
            d = 1  # Shift by 1 to the left
            segment = array[l:r]

            array[l:r] = shifted_segment

    return results

    sorted_arr = sorted(arr)
    
    if arr == sorted_arr:
        return operations  # Already sorted, no operations needed
    
    # Simple strategy: bubble sort-like approach using cyclic shifts
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n - 1):
            if arr[j] > arr[j + 1]:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to swap arr[j] and arr[j+1]
                cyclic_shift(arr, j, j + 1, 1)
                operations.append((j + 1, j + 2, 1))
    
    return operations

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    results = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        arr = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        
        operations = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(n, arr)
        results.append((len(operations), operations))
    
    for k, ops in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in ops:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

prompt:
The new generation external memory includes an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. However, it allows for a different kind of operation that can be used to modify the array. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you substitute the segment a[l … r] with its cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 


For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
